title: Middle East on edge: Cabinet meeting set to seal Israels plans for potential Iran strike - Lebanon News
text: News Latest News news bulletin Breaking Headlines Israel-Gaza War Updates Variety and Tech Sports News Middle East News World News Lebanon News Press Highlights Lebanon Economy News Bulletin Reports Other News Breaking Headlines Israel-Gaza War Updates Variety and Tech Sports News Middle East News World News Lebanon News Press Highlights Lebanon Economy News Bulletin Reports Beirut 20 o Bekaa 8 o Keserwan 22 o Metn 22 o Mount Lebanon 14 o North 20 o South 18 o Live Video Audio Schedule shows العربية watching now News SUBSCRIBE Home Notification Live Video Audio shows Beirut 20 o Bekaa 8 o Keserwan 22 o Metn 22 o Mount Lebanon 14 o North 20 o South 18 o News Programs The News Breaking Headlines Israel-Gaza War Updates Variety and Tech Sports News Middle East News World News Lebanon News Press Highlights Lebanon Economy News Bulletin Reports Programs Documentaries Lebanon’s Centennial Movies News Bulletin The Untold History Talk Show Series Sports Variety Other Comedy Oldies Breaking News Latest News Highlighted News Most Read Videos العربية Watch the latest programs and the latest developments on your favorite screen Shows Join millions of followers LBCI Lebanon LBCI News Who We Are Contact Us Advertise With Us Careers Channel frequencies Privacy Policy Terms and Conditions Middle East on edge: Cabinet meeting set to seal Israel's plans for potential Iran strike News Bulletin Reports 2024-10-24 | 19:50 High views Share Share 2 min Middle East on edge: Cabinet meeting set to seal Israel's plans for potential Iran strike Report by Amal Shehadeh, English adaptation by Yasmine Jaroudi While Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu scheduled a cabinet meeting involving top security officials for Sunday, Israel appears to be nearing a military strike on Iran. This comes after U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken failed to persuade Netanyahu to opt for a more moderate approach. Israeli security agencies have confirmed that the strike could happen within days, with the Israeli Air Force and missile defense systems readying for a potential Iranian response. The U.S. THAAD missile defense system has been deployed, particularly in southern Israel, to counter any ballistic missile threats from Iran. Concerns now center on possible Russian support for Iran in countering Israeli missiles, which could shield Tehran from a severe blow. Meanwhile, Israeli airstrikes continue across Lebanon, reaching as far as Beirut. U.S. Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin, in a conversation with his Israeli counterpart Yoav Gallant, expressed Washington's concern over Israeli strikes targeting the Lebanese Army and UNIFIL forces. On the ground, senior Israeli officers have revealed that five Israeli brigades are preparing for several weeks of battles in Lebanon in order to dismantle Hezbollah's infrastructure, particularly in villages along the frontline. In response, Hezbollah continues its rocket and drone attacks on northern Israel and as far as Tel Aviv, despite a media blackout on Israeli military casualties. Israeli Chief of Staff Herzi Halevi has insisted on maintaining the secrecy of military base locations to prevent Hezbollah from gaining tactical advantages.
